title: Department of the Air Force, FAA clear SpaceX to launch up to 120 Falcon 9 rockets annually from Cape Canaveral
summary: The move not only allows SpaceX to increase its allowed launches at pad 40 from 50 to 120, but it also permits the Texas-based company to construct a new landing site adjacent to the launch pad.
detailed_news: The FAA and the Department of the Air Force gave the green light for SpaceX to more than double its launch cadence from its workhorse launch pad in Florida. The FAA issued a 21-page document called a Mitigated Finding of No Significant Impact and Record of Decision (FONSI/ROD) The FAA is currently working through the EIS process when it comes to bringing SpaceX’s massive Starship rocket to Florida. The Final EA was published this week by the U.S. Department of the Interior. SpaceX is required to conduct species monitoring for creatures like sea turtles, the Florida scrub-jay and the southeastern beach mouse. The FAA determined that plans proposed by SpaceX as evaluated by the Final EA wouldn’t violate the relevant section of the Endangered Species Act. SpaceX's Proposed Action includes construction of a new landing zone at SLC-40. It would consist of a 280-foot diameter concrete pad with a 60-foot-wide gravel apron. Roughly two acres of Florida scrub-jay and about seven acres of a combination of grassy areas, existing roads and infrastructure would be impacted. SpaceX announced during the launch campaign of the Crew-11 mission to the International Space Station that it would end its use of LZ-1 with that mission. SpaceX launched 60 more Starlink internet satellites at 10:59 p.m. EST Monday (0359 GMT Tuesday) aboard a Falcon 9 rocket from pad 40 at Cape Canaveral.

title: New U.S. military satellite constellation takes shape with first launch from Vandenberg SFB
summary: The Space Development Agency’s Proliferated Warfighter Space Architecture constellation is expected to deliver global coverage beginning in 2027. Launch from Vandenberg Space Force Base occurred at 7:12 a.m. PDT (10:12 a.m. EDT / 1412 UTC).
detailed_news: The Space Development Agency took a big step in realizing a new satellite constellation to support the various branches of the U.S. military and its allies. This was the first in a series of six launches for what it calls the Transport Layer of space vehicles. The mission began with a SpaceX Falcon 9 launch from Vandenberg Space Force Base. The first T1TL satellites will go through some early testing and then will be used by some early adopters within about four to six months. Sandhoo said that will primarily be the U.S. Indo-Pacific Command, one of six Unified Combatant Commands. “This is the first time we’ll have a space layer actually fully integrated into our war fighting operations,” he added.

title: A Brief Outburst
summary: The NASA-ESA Solar and Heliospheric Observatory (SOHO) spacecraft captured this extreme ultraviolet wavelength image of the Sun on Feb. 24, 2015, during a three-hour period in which our closest star blew out a coronal mass ejection along with part of a solar filament. While some of the strands fell back into the Sun, a substantial […]
detailed_news: The NASA-ESA Solar and Heliospheric Observatory (SOHO) captured this extreme ultraviolet wavelength image of the Sun on Feb. 24, 2015. Soon, there will be three new ways to study the Sun’s influence across the solar system with the launch of a trio of NASA and NOAA spacecraft.

title: NASA’s GUARDIAN Tsunami Detection Tech Catches Wave in Real Time
summary: A massive earthquake and subsequent tsunami off Russia in late July tested an experimental detection system that had deployed a critical component just the day before. A recent tsunami triggered by a magnitude 8.8 earthquake off Russia’s Kamchatka Peninsula sent pressure waves to the upper layer of the atmosphere, NASA scientists have reported. While the […]
detailed_news: A massive earthquake and subsequent tsunami off Russia in late July tested an experimental detection system. The system flagged distortions in the atmosphere and issued notifications to subscribed subject matter experts. Within about 10 minutes of receiving data, it can produce a snapshot of a tsunami’s rumble. Tsunamis are most often caused by large undersea earthquakes, but not always. Volcanic eruptions, underwater landslides, and certain weather conditions in some geographic locations can all produce dangerous waves. Key to this effort is the network of GNSS stations around the world supported by NASA.

title: Cailabs Raises €57M to Ramp Up Production of Optical Ground Station
summary:
French optical communication systems provider Cailabs has secured €57 million in new funding that it will use to scale production of its optical ground stations. Founded in 2013, Cailabs offers a range of laser-based solutions for a wide range of terrestrial and space applications. Among these is an off-the-shelf optical ground station that is designed […]
The post Cailabs Raises €57M to Ramp Up Production of Optical Ground Station appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: French optical communication systems provider Cailabs has secured €57 million in new funding. The company plans to use the new funding to scale production to as many as 50 units per year by 2027. The new funding will support the company’s expansion into new markets and the development of new products.

title: Week in images: 08-12 September 2025
summary: Week in images: 08-12 September 2025
detailed_news: CNN.com will feature iReporter photos in a weekly Travel Snapshots gallery. Please submit your best shots for next week. Visit CNN.com/Travel next Wednesday for a new gallery of snapshots. Click here for the next gallery of iReporters' snapshots.

title: Artemis II Crew  to Advance Human Spaceflight Research
summary: A sweeping collection of astronaut health studies planned for NASA’s Artemis II mission around the Moon will soon provide agency researchers with a glimpse into how deep space travel influences the human body, mind, and behavior. During an approximately 10-day mission set to launch in 2026, NASA astronauts Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover, and Christina Koch, […]
detailed_news: Astronauts will collect and store their saliva, don wrist monitors that track movement and sleep. One study will explore how the immune system reacts to spaceflight. The findings are expected to provide vital insights for future missions to destinations beyond low Earth orbit, including Mars. “The lessons we learn from this crew will help us to more safely accomplish deep space missions and research,” an engineer says. Artemis missions will be the farthest NASA astronauts have ventured into space since the Apollo era. NASA also plans to use the Artemis II mission to help scientists characterize the radiation environment in deep space. Several CubeSats, shoe-box sized satellites that will be deployed into high-Earth orbit during Orion’s transit to the Moon, will probe the near and deep space radiation environment. NASA explores the unknown in air and space, innovates for the benefit of humanity, and inspires the world through discovery. Living in Space Artemis Human Research Program Space Station Research and Technology NASA explores the known and unknown in space and air, innovating for thebenefit of humanity.

title: How carrying enough water to make return-trip propellant simplifies a Starship mission to Mars
summary:
The idea of a human mission to explore Mars has been studied repeatedly over the past 75 years. More than 1,000 piloted Mars mission studies were conducted inside and outside NASA between about 1950 and 2000. Many were the product of NASA and industry study teams, while others were the work of committed individuals or […]

summary: Group photo taken at the General Assembly on Defence, Space and Cybersecurity, held on Friday 12 September 2025, at ESRIN, ESA’s Centre for Earth Observation Programmes in Italy.
detailed_news: General Assembly on Defence, Space and Cybersecurity, held on Friday 12 September 2025, at ESRIN, ESA’s Centre for Earth Observation Programmes in Italy. Event organised by the European Parliament and the European Commission, in collaboration with the European Space Agency. Representatives from major European entities debated the future of the European Union.

title: Hubble Surveys Cloudy Cluster
summary: This new NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope image features a cloudy starscape from an impressive star cluster. This scene is in the Large Magellanic Cloud, a dwarf galaxy situated about 160,000 light-years away in the constellations Dorado and Mensa. With a mass equal to 10–20% of the mass of the Milky Way, the Large Magellanic Cloud […]
detailed_news: This scene is in the Large Magellanic Cloud, a dwarf galaxy situated about 160,000 light-years away. We see bright, young stars lighting up the gas clouds and sculpting clumps of dust with powerful ultraviolet radiation. This image marries observations made roughly 20 years apart, a testament to Hubble’s longevity.

title: Drag Prediction Workshop Series
summary: The Drag Prediction Workshop series is an extensive international effort to improve transonic aerodynamic predictions. This long-running collaborative effort seeks to mobilize the international aerospace community to improve the computational methods and tools to predict transonic aircraft performance, particularly drag. More details on the workshop can be found at the workshop website: https://www.aiaa-dpw.org NASA has […]
detailed_news: The Drag Prediction Workshop series is an international effort to improve transonic aerodynamic predictions. The series also resulted in the NASA/Boeing Common Research Model. NASA’s contributions to the upcoming DPW-8 and subsequent work will be highlighted on this page.

title: Avio Approves €400M Capital Increase to Expand Defence and Rocket Production
summary:
Italian rocket builder Avio’s Board of Directors has approved a €400 million capital increase to fund an expansion of its manufacturing capacity to meet rising demand in the global space and defence markets. Announced on 12 September, the capital raise is part of a new ten-year business plan targeting an average annual growth rate of […]
The post Avio Approves €400M Capital Increase to Expand Defence and Rocket Production appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: Italian rocket builder Avio’s Board of Directors has approved a €400 million capital increase. The capital raise is part of a new ten-year business plan targeting an average annual growth rate of about 10% in turnover. This growth will be driven by a higher Vega C launch cadence, the introduction of Vega E, and continued participation in the Ariane 6 programme.

title: Earth from Space: Gibson Desert, Australia
summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: Part of the Gibson Desert in Western Australia is featured in this image, captured by the Φsat-2 mission in June 2025. Covering an area of over 150 000 sq km, the desert consists of gravel terrains covered by desert grasses, as well as red sandy plains and dune fields. Parallel dune ridges are a defining characteristic of the area and can be seen spreading across the image.

title: Europe celebrates 30 years of satellite navigation
summary: On 2 September 2025, the European Space Agency (ESA) opened the doors of ESTEC, its research and technology centre, to celebrate 30 years of European satellite navigation. Partners from across the continent gathered for a sensational event that took the audience on a journey through time, honouring the achievements and collaboration that have shaped this success story.
detailed_news: The European Space Agency (ESA) opened the doors of ESTEC, its research and technology centre, to celebrate 30 years of European satellite navigation. Partners from across the continent gathered for a sensational event that took the audience on a journey through time. A photo exhibition invited visitors to reminisce about the beginnings of EGNOS and Galileo, while a captivating show brought to life incredible milestones. The 135th PB-NAV has been a cornerstone in guiding ESA’s navigation strategy. It has shaped policy and execution of key EU projects Galileo and EGNOS, and even beyond with FutureNAV and NAVISP. Delegates discussed proposals for the Council at Ministerial Level, to be held this November.

title: Columbus: 100 000 orbits and counting
summary: Today, the Columbus laboratory aboard the International Space Station completes its 100 000th orbit around Earth—a remarkable achievement for Europe’s science module in space.
detailed_news: The Columbus laboratory aboard the International Space Station completes its 100 000th orbit around Earth. Since its launch in 2008, Columbus has been a hub of research and innovation, orbiting at 28 800 km/h and approximately 400 km above Earth. It has hosted astronauts from over 20 countries, and supported hundreds of experiments that explore everything from human health to advanced materials.

title: House Appropriators Approve FY2026 Budget for NASA
summary: The House Appropriations Committee approved the FY2026 Commerce-Justice-Science (CJS) bill last evening including funding for NASA. The committee disagreed with the Trump Administration’s proposal to cut NASA’s budget by 24.3 […]
detailed_news: The House Appropriations Committee approved the FY2026 Commerce-Justice-Science (CJS) bill last evening including funding for NASA. The committee disagreed with the Trump Administration’s proposal to cut NASA's budget by 24.3 percent and instead keeps the agency at roughly the same level as FY2025 — $24.8 billion. title: NASA found intriguing rocks on Mars, so where does that leave Mars Sample Return?
summary: "I have to look at dollars, and I have to look at time, and I have to look at return."
detailed_news: NASA's interim administrator Sean Duffy joined a teleconference to talk about new scientific findings that concerned the potential for life to have once existed on Mars. Duffy was ready to discuss the scientific results along with NASA experts on the call with reporters. But the very first question concerned NASA's on-again, off-again plan to return rocks from the surface of Mars for study on Earth. Interim NASA administrator is open to negotiating with Congress about the best path forward. It has already been a turbulent year for the Trump administration and NASA's science programs. The White House, NASA, and Congress already face a host of thorny questions about the future of more than two dozen science missions.

title: NASA Armstrong to Host Partnership Day Oct. 21-22
summary: NASA’s Armstrong Flight Research Center in Edwards, California, invites innovative companies, government agencies, and organizations to attend Partnership Days, scheduled for Oct. 21-22, 2025, at the center. The event offers a unique opportunity to explore collaboration with NASA on cutting-edge research and development in areas such as aerospace, autonomy, sustainability, and more. Attendees will engage […]
detailed_news: NASA’s Armstrong Flight Research Center in Edwards, California, invites innovative companies, government agencies, and organizations to attend Partnership Days. The event offers a unique opportunity to explore collaboration with NASA on cutting-edge research and development. Space is limited, and RSVP is required by Sept. 26.

Their commitment to the NASA mission represents the entrepreneurial spirit, technical expertise, and collaborative disposition needed to explore this world and beyond. Earth Science Star: […]

Their commitment to the NASA mission represents the entrepreneurial spirit, technical expertise, and collaborative disposition needed to explore this world and beyond. Park is the Project Scientist for the Wildfire, Ecosystem Resilience, & Risk Assessment project.

title: NASA, Embry-Riddle Enact Agreement to Advance Research, Educational Opportunities
summary: As NASA inspires the world through discovery in a new era of innovation and exploration, NASA’s Langley Research Center in Hampton, Virginia, and Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University are working together to advance research, educational opportunities, and workforce development to enable the next generation of aerospace breakthroughs. The collaborative work will happen through a Space Act Agreement […]
detailed_news: NASA Langley Research Center and Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University sign a Space Act Agreement. The agreement will leverage NASA Langley’s aerospace expertise to drive innovation in aerospace, research, education, and technology. It will also develop a highly skilled workforce for the future of space exploration and advanced air mobility.

title: Shining Pismis 24
summary: NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope captured this sparkling scene of star birth in an image released on Sept. 4, 2025. Called Pismis 24, this young star cluster resides in the core of the nearby Lobster Nebula, approximately 5,500 light-years from Earth in the constellation Scorpius. Home to a vibrant stellar nursery and one of the […]
detailed_news: NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope captured this sparkling scene of star birth in an image released on Sept. 4, 2025. Called Pismis 24, this young star cluster resides in the core of the nearby Lobster Nebula, approximately 5,500 light-years from Earth.

title: New U.S.-European Sea Level Satellite Will Help Safeguard Ships at Sea
summary: Sea surface height data from the Sentinel-6B satellite, led by NASA and ESA, will help with the development of marine weather forecasts, alerting ships to possible dangers. Because most global trade travels by ship, accurate, timely ocean forecasts are essential. These forecasts provide crucial information about storms, high winds, and rough water, and they depend […]
detailed_news: Sentinel-6B will provide essential sea level and other ocean data after it launches this November. The satellite will eventually take over from its twin, Sentinel-6 Michael Freilich, which launched in 2020. Both satellites have an altimeter instrument that measures sea levels, wind speeds, and wave heights, among other characteristics. Sentinel-6B will extend a long-term dataset featuring more than 30 years of sea level measurements. The dataset has turned this dataset into the gold standard sea level measurement from space. “This kind of data can’t be easily replaced,” said Mehra.

title: Artemis II Crew Both Subjects and Scientists in NASA Deep Space Research
summary: With Artemis II, NASA is taking the science of living and working in space beyond low Earth orbit. While the test flight will help confirm the systems and hardware needed for human deep space exploration, the crew also will be serving as both scientists and volunteer research subjects, completing a suite of experiments that will […]
detailed_news: NASA's Artemis II mission will explore how deep space travel affects sleep, stress, cognition, and teamwork. Results will help the agency build future interventions, protocols, and preventative measures to best protect astronauts on future missions to the lunar surface and to Mars. Saliva provides a unique window into how the human immune system functions in a deep space environment. AVATAR could inform measures to ensure crew health on future deep space missions, including personalizing medical kits to each astronaut. The Artemis II crew will take advantage of their location to explore the Moon from above. As the first humans to see the lunar surface up close since 1972, they’ll document their observations through photographs and audio recordings. Artemis II will be the first mission to integrate science flight control operations. The crew will be equipped with questions that scientists didn’t even know to ask during Apollo missions. Lessons learned during Artemis II will pave the way for lunar science operations on future missions. Several additional experiments are hitching a ride to space onboard Artemis II in the form of CubeSats – shoe-box-sized technology demonstrations.

title: NASA’s Northrop Grumman CRS-23 Infographics & Hardware
summary: NASA’s Northrop Grumman Commercial Resupply Services 23, or Northrop Grumman CRS-23, will deliver more than 11,000 pounds of science and supplies to the International Space Station. This mission will be the first flight of the Cygnus XL, the larger, more cargo-capable version of the company’s solar-powered spacecraft. The Cygnus XL will launch on a SpaceX […]
detailed_news: Northrop Grumman CRS-23 will deliver more than 11,000 pounds of science and supplies to the International Space Station. This mission will be the first flight of the Cygnus XL, the larger, more cargo-capable version of the company’s solar-powered spacecraft. The Upper, X, Y, and Z Isolator Assemblies are launching as spares for the space station’s treadmill. Quick Don Mask Assembly – This mask is used by the crew, along with the Pre-Breath Assembly, in emergency situations. Anomaly Gas Analyzer – This analyzer senses various gases, like oxygen, carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, ammonia, and others.

title: After Biosignature Announcement, Mars Sample Return Remains in Limbo
summary: Ambitious plans by NASA and the European Space Agency to return samples of the Martian surface to Earth continue to remain in limbo even as the Agency has announced the collection of a potentially biosignature-containing sample aboard the Perseverance rover.
detailed_news: NASA and the European Space Agency have announced the collection of a potentially biosignature-containing sample aboard the Perseverance rover. This sample, stored in a tube inside the rover, is intended for return to earth on a future Mars Sample Return mission. This tantalizing discovery may provide a renewed sense of urgency for Martian exploration within the second Trump administration. The potential game-changing nature of the Sapphire Canyon sample adds new urgency to the future of the Mars Sample Return program. China has announced plans to launch their own Mars sample return mission as early as 2028. Europe, meanwhile, appears intent on further developing its own Martian capabilities.

title: ispace-Europe Completes Key Milestone for ESA MAGPIE Lunar Lander
summary:
Luxembourg-based ispace-Europe has completed the Mission Definition Review for the European Space Agency’s MAGPIE lunar lander mission. The Mission for Advanced Geophysics and Polar Ice Exploration (MAGPIE) is designed to prospect for water ice in the Moon’s south polar region. It will also map the distribution of hydrogen and study the geological history of the […]
The post ispace-Europe Completes Key Milestone for ESA MAGPIE Lunar Lander appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: Luxembourg-based ispace-Europe has completed the Mission Definition Review for the European Space Agency’s MAGPIE lunar lander mission. The Mission for Advanced Geophysics and Polar Ice Exploration (MAGPIE) is designed to prospect for water ice in the Moon's south polar region. It will also map the distribution of hydrogen and study the geological history of the area.

title: ispace-Europe Completes Key Milestone for ESA MAGPIE Lunar Rover
summary:
Luxembourg-based ispace-Europe has completed the Mission Definition Review for the European Space Agency’s MAGPIE lunar rover mission. It will also map the distribution of hydrogen and study the geological history of the […]

The Mission for Advanced Geophysics and Polar Ice Exploration (MAGPIE) is designed to prospect for water ice in the Moon's south polar region. It will also map the distribution of hydrogen and study the geological history of the area.

title: Sentinel-1D in French Guiana for launch campaign
summary: The fourth satellite for the Copernicus Sentinel-1 mission, Sentinel-1D, has arrived at Félix Eboué airport, the main airport in French Guiana. From there the spacecraft, safely stored in its protective casing, will be transported to launch preparation facilities at the European Spaceport in Kourou.
detailed_news: The fourth satellite for the Copernicus Sentinel-1 mission has arrived at Félix Eboué airport, the main airport in French Guiana. It will be transported to launch preparation facilities at the European Spaceport in Kourou. This is the start of a launch campaign that will lead up to the launch date, still to be announced. The satellite will reach its orbit on board an Ariane 6.

title: Progress MS-32 set for launch to ISS from Baikonur
summary:
Just over two weeks after the CRS-33 cargo delivery to the International Space Station, another…
The post Progress MS-32 set for launch to ISS from Baikonur appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: The Progress MS-32 cargo ship is scheduled to dock with the International Space Station on Saturday, Sept. 13. The docking, as is usual for Progress craft, will be automated, but with a manual backup available for use if needed. The Progress spacecraft can carry up to 2,140 kg of trash for disposal. Kurs-NA requires just one phased array antenna as opposed to the old system’s use of four. The new system is also lighter and uses less power, with additional computerization, while being manufactured entirely in Russia. The TORU capability was last used in 2021, when current Station commander, Ryzhikov, used the manual backup to successfully dock Progress MS-16.

title: Plato arrived at ESA’s test centre by boat
summary: The European Space Agency’s Plato spacecraft has safely arrived at ESTEC, ESA’s technical heart in the Netherlands. There, engineers will complete the spacecraft by connecting its solar panels and sunshield, and carry out a series of critical tests to confirm that Plato is fit for launch and ready for its planet-hunting mission in space.
detailed_news: Plato is scheduled to launch on an Ariane 6 rocket in December 2026. It will search for Earth-like planets orbiting stars similar to our Sun. The spacecraft is equipped with 26 ultrasensitive cameras designed to capture the tiniest variations in the intensity of a star’s light.

title: House appropriators offer support to threatened NASA missions
summary:
House appropriators offered support, but no specific funding, for several NASA missions slated for cancellation in the administration’s 2026 budget proposal.
The post House appropriators offer support to threatened NASA missions appeared first on SpaceNews.

summary:
Italian startup Astradyne has secured €2 million in seed funding to accelerate the development of its Solar-Z product, a lightweight solar array designed to enhance the capabilities of small satellites. Astradyne was founded in 2021 with the aim of developing an off-the-shelf deployable solar array for small satellites that is lighter, more compact, and more […]

title: Eutelsat opens OneWeb ground stations to Earth observation with Ka-band boost
summary:
Eutelsat has teamed up with French satellite connectivity startup Skynopy to offer Earth observation operators spare capacity on the ground stations used for OneWeb, its LEO broadband service.

title: House Passes FY2026 NDAA
summary: The House passed the FY2026 National Defense Authorization Act this evening, authorizing funding for the U.S. Space Force and other components of the Department of Defense.  Only a fraction of […]
detailed_news: The House passed the FY2026 National Defense Authorization Act this evening. Only a fraction of the amendments offered to the NDAA were allowed to be debated on the floor. One that was not cleared would have overturned a requirement in the reconciliation bill to move a space vehicle — likely the Space Shuttle Discovery — from Virginia to Houston.

title: Mars Samples Must Be Returned To Earth to Prove If Life Existed There
summary: A rock sample discovered by NASA’s Mars Perseverance Rover last year may hold proof that life once existed on Mars, but scientists need to get the sample back to Earth […]
detailed_news: A rock sample discovered by NASA’s Mars Perseverance Rover may hold proof that life once existed on Mars. The finding that the sample shows the best evidence so far of past microbial life on the Red Planet was revealed last year and published today in Nature. Analysis by more sophisticated tools in laboratories here on Earth is the only way to be absolutely certain. How to do Mars Sample Return more cost effectively and on a shorter time frame remains unclear. Eight companies replied to NASA’s request for ideas last year, but none were sufficient for NASA to make a decision before the change in administrations. Earlier problems and budget uncertainty forced JPL to lay off 13 percent of its workforce in 2024.

title: NASA Unveils Potential Evidence of Ancient Martian Life in Peculiar Rock Patterns
summary:
An international team of scientists has revealed that unusual leopard-spot patterns on a Martian rock…
The post NASA Unveils Potential Evidence of Ancient Martian Life in Peculiar Rock Patterns appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: An international team of scientists has revealed that unusual leopard-spot patterns on a Martian rock may hold clues to ancient microbial life on the Red Planet. The rock, dubbed Cheyava Falls, was discovered by NASA’s Perseverance rover in June 2024 within the ancient river valley of Neretva Vallis. Cheyava Falls is among the youngest sedimentary rocks analyzed by Perseverance. This challenges earlier assumptions that biosignatures would only survive in formations far older than those currently known. This has reignited discussions about NASA’s Mars Sample Return (MSR) mission, which aims to bring Martian rocks back to Earth.

title: NASA highlights potential evidence of past life in Martian rock
summary:
Scientists have found potential evidence of past life on Mars in a rock sample collected by a NASA rover, even as a proposed budget cancels plans to return those samples.
The post NASA highlights potential evidence of past life in Martian rock appeared first on SpaceNews.

title: NASA Uses Colorado Mountains for Simulated Artemis Moon Landing Course
summary: NASA has certified a new lander flight training course using helicopters, marking a key milestone in crew training for Artemis missions to the Moon. Through Artemis, NASA explore the lunar South Pole, paving the way for human exploration farther into the solar system, including Mars.  The mountains in northern Colorado offer similar visual illusions and […]
detailed_news: NASA has certified a new lander flight training course using helicopters. The course is a key milestone in crew training for Artemis missions to the Moon. Through Artemis, NASA explore the lunar South Pole, paving the way for human exploration farther into the solar system, including Mars. The NASA-focused course has been in development since 2021. NASA will send astronauts to explore the Moon for scientific discovery, economic benefits, and to build the foundation for the first crewed missions to Mars. NASA explores the unknown in air and space, innovates for the benefit of humanity, and inspires the world through discovery. For more information about Artemis visit: https://www.nasa.gov/artemis.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX attempts to launch Indonesian communications satellite following back-to-back weather scrubs
summary: The launch once again faces long odds with poor weather in the forecast for a third day in a row. SpaceX is targeting liftoff from pad 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station at 8 p.m. EDT (0000 UTC).
detailed_news: Possible technical issues got in the way of a launch attempt Wednesday evening after back-to-back days of weather delays. The Nusantara Lima (N5) satellite will be sent into a geosynchronous transfer orbit roughly 27 minutes after liftoff. The satellite is built on the same Boeing-built bus used on Intelsat’s IS-33e spacecraft, which suffered an anomaly in 2024.

title: The Earth Observer Editor’s Corner: July–September 2025
summary: NOTE TO READERS: After more than three decades associated with or directly employed by NASA, Steve Platnick [GSFC—Deputy Director for Atmospheres, Earth Sciences Division] stepped down effective August 8, 2025. Steve began his civil servant career at GSFC in 2002, but his GSFC association went back to 1993, first as a contractor and then as […]
detailed_news: Steve Platnick stepped down effective August 8, 2025. Platnick played an integral role in the sustainability and advancement of NASA’s Earth Observing System platforms and data. NISAR will use two different radar frequencies to penetrate clouds and forest canopies. Combining data from these two radars will allow researchers to systematically and globally map Earth. The radar reflector will be used to direct and receive microwave signals from the two radars. By interpreting the differences between the L-band and S-band measurements, researchers will be able to discern characteristics about the surface below. As NISAR passes over the same locations twice every 12 days, scientists can evaluate how those characteristics have changed over time. The OCO mission hasn’t just about been about data and hardware. The human stories woven through the mission’s successes and setbacks are really what holds the mission together. OCO-3 extends the global CO 2 measurement record while adding new capabilities made possible by being on ISS. GEDI’s lasers have been operating nominally and the mission has continued to produce high-quality observations. The 2025 GEDI Science Team Meeting (STM) brought together the mission science team, competed science team. Compton J. Tucker retired from NASA in March 2025 after 48 years of public service. He was among 149 newly elected members to the National Academy of Sciences.  Compton's research achievements and all of the other scientific awards and honors received throughout his career. NASA explores the unknown in air and space, innovates for the benefit of humanity, and inspires the world through discovery, says Barry Lefer Associate Director of Research, Earth Science Division.
